title: What will be the all-time count of pro-Kremlin disinformation cases identified by the European Union External Action Service's East StratCom Task Force as of 18 April 2019?
preds: Update: the question deadline is tomorrow and today the all-time amount of disinformation cases is 5321. It'sreally unlikely that the final amount will exceed the 5500 cases.

Julian King, the Commission’s security chief, said the EU had identified “3,500 examples of pro-Kremlin disinformation contradicting publicly available facts repeated in many languages on many occasions”. - https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/russian-fake-news-disinformation-europe-putin-trump-eu-european-parliament-commission-a8164526.html as of january 2018 so a year later it must increase

UPDATE 16.04.2019
All-time amount of disinformation cases at the time of forecasting (16.04.2019 at 22:46 a.m. CET): 5264
Days remaining: 2 (including today)
Change since last forecast: 104  104 / 14 days (03.04 to 16.04) = 7,43 per day The number of disinformation cases per day increased slightly. However, this increase wasn't high enough at all. It is (realistically) very unlikely that the amount of disinformation cases will exceed the threshold of 5500 cases.  The forecast will be adjusted accordingly to 100% for "More than 4900 but less than 5500".

Disinformation will rise in connection with  European elections and Brexit. Russia will improve the credibility of the disinformation, partly by reducing the rate of increase in the  number of incidents

As of today (13th of April), the number of identified disinformation cases is 5265. Based on previous trends, my prognosis is that it will not exceed the number of 5500. 
First, if we look at statistics provided by the European UnionÍs East StratCom Task Force, we can see that during the last week 36 cases were identified, for the last month - 198 cases. From the topics of the latest disinformation cases, it is clear that a lot of attention gets Ukraine and, especially, the 2019 Ukrainian Presidential Election. Therefore, it is important to take into account that the second round of the election will be held on next Sunday. It is very likely to trigger the number of disinformation cases. However, even though the higher number can be expected, it should not change dramatically from the previous numbers.
Will get worse with Brexit and more surveillance.

Update
12/04/2019: all-time count of 5265 pro-Kremlin disinformation cases.
Russia could increase its disinformation case in the next week because of Ukraine elections, but I exclude the possibility that the all-time count will exceed 5500 cases.

Update: 
11/04/2019: all time count of 5265 pro-Kremlin disinformation cases.

As of a week from April 18th the counter stood at 5265 and the past week saw 48 disinformation cases. Thereby, to reach over 5500 cases in under a week a staggering 235 cases would need to be reported, which is more than were reported in the last month (227). While Russia will likely significantly increase its disinformation in these final days of the Ukrainian Presidency election, I find it 0% believable that Russia would increase it's already ramped up campaigns by over 500% for just one semi important election.
Seeing as the 18th of April is approaching, and the current count is on 5209, is becomes unrealistic to assume that the count will pass 5500.  Source: https://euvsdisinfo.eu/

In the post-Soviet era, disinformation evolved to become a key tactic in the military doctrine of Russia.The EU and NATO see Russian disinformation as such a problem that they both set up special units to analyze and uncover fabricated stories. In March 2015 the EU created the European External Action Service East Stratcom Task Force, which publishes weekly reports in its website 'EU vs Disinfo'. The website and its partners identified and debunked over 3,500 pro-Kremlin disinformation cases between September 2015 and November 2017, which means between 1512 to 1750 per year. At the moment when this forecast is made - 10.04.2019 - there have been 5209 cases recorded, which renders it relatively safe to assume that within a week's time the total number will not exceed 5500. I am 95% confident that this will remain so. It is also clear why the options below that number are outruled. Statistics for the past three years (2016-2018) indicate a monthly average of 126 cases, which means that it would take another 2.4 months for the number to exceed 5500.  There is a very small chance that the numbers will increase above the upper threshold. We can speculate that major events such as Brexit, the EU Parliament or Ukrainian elections will affect the tenacity of misinformation efforts, which is confirmed by the data available for the past month: during the month of March which was characterised by high uncertainty around the departure of the UK fromt the EU as well as the first round in the Ukrainian presidential race, 177 cases between the beginning of March until today, exceeding the monthly average by roughly 50 cases. As shown by history, RUssia has a particular interest in Ukraine's domestic politics.  A report titled 'How Russian media foments hostility towards West' published by the Black Sea Trust for Regional Cooperation and the Hybrid Warfare Analytical Group of Ukraine Crisis Media Centershows that the Russian Pervyi Kanal is represented in the 5000+ database with 440 cases, many of which come from the Vremya Pokazhet program wihch historically has been engaging in bashing Ukraine. The latest disinformation from that show exists in the database is about the West pushing Poroshenko to power again and him using a military clash with Russia to postpone the election. In second place is Rossiya 1 with 295 cases in the database. The talk shows 60 Minut and Vecher s Vladimirom Solovyovym have a high potential to try to manipulate the framing of the Ukrainian elections (e.g. "The outcome of Ukrainian election will be decided in Washington"). This indicates that it is likely that the Ukrainian elections in 2019 will lead to an increase in the number of cases in the month of April, when the second round will take place. However, there have been 0 cases recorded in the last week.
Although the numbers contained in the EU report may or may not be absolute, it is very unlikely that the numbers will exceed my forecast.

Routine update on my forecast: I'm getting more confident that it will end in the 4900-5500 bracket. With ten days left the count is at 5200. The were more cases each month than expected in my very first forecast (around 180 cases instead of 140.) Adjusting for this, less than 5500 is still the best option. I'm leaving a couple percent in the 5500-6300 bracket because of irreducible uncertainty.

Update: 
Today the all time count is of 5209 cases https://euvsdisinfo.eu. As April 18th is approaching, I set an even higher probability for the option of "More than 4900 but less than 5500"

UPDATE 03.04.2019 
All-time amount of disinformation cases at the time of forecasting (03.04.2019 at 09:33 a.m. CET): 5160 
Days remaining: 16 (including today) Change since last forecast: 53 -> 53 / 8 (26.03 to 02.04) = 6,63 
Estimated cases at the end of 18.04 with a steady base rate of 6,63 cases per day: 6,63 * 16 = 106,08 
106 + 5160 = 5266 Necessary base rate to exceed 5500-threshold: 
Difference between threshold and current number: 5500 - 5160 = 340 
Necessary daily base rate -> 340 /  16 (remaining days) = 21,25 
Total difference between actual base rate and necessary base rate-> 21,25 - 6,63 = 14,62   
Necessary increase of current base rate -> 14,62 / 6,63 = 2,21

Old upper estimate (see last forecast) was at roughly 5240 cases which means that there is an actual increase in the base rate beyond the 'upper estimated base rate'. As argued before, the EU elections should be attractive to disinformation campaigns. However, the last forecast didn't account for the Ukrainian election which represents a highly attractive target for disinformation cases, too. The increase of the base rate beyond its estimated maximum level is based on the (more or less) simultaneous election periods. The effect of the Ukrainian election should hold on due to the extension into the second round which ends mid-April. Nonetheless, it is very likely that the (current and future) increase of the base rate won’t be enough regarding the fact that it has to increase by the factor 2,2 in order to reach the threshold of 5500 cases. As a result, the probability for this case will be set down to 1%, while the probability for the 6300 threshold vanishes to 0%. The 1% probability reflects the uncertainty involved in such propaganda campaigns.  (Disclaimer: the version before stated a 3% probability for the 5500 threshold and a 1% likelihood for the 6300-threshold. After taking account of other forecasts by GJO users I adjusted mine. The reason lies in the practicality of the forecast itself. While there are still arguments for a 1% chance for the 6300-threshold, this outcome seems practically 'non-existent'.) Sources: 
EU vs Disinfo (2019): Key statistics of disinformation: https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ EU vs Disinfo(2019): “Ukraine will turn into a banana republic”: Ukrainian elections on Russian TV: https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ukraine-will-turn-into-a-banana-republic-ukrainian-elections-on-russian-tv/  BBC 2019: Ukraine election: Comedian leads presidential contest - exit poll: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-47767440

Seeing as there are currently 5160 cases and there were 297 cases reported in the past month, it’s likely that the number on the 18th will be less than 5500. However, since elections are coming up in Ukraine and other European countries, there may be an increase in cases, so there is a small chance that the number of cases could go above 5500. It does not seem likely that the cases would exceed 6300, as there would have to be over a 1000 cases in the next 16 days.

As of today, the number of cases is 5160. In the past year, approximately 100 new cases per month were added to the website. In 2016, a busier year, approx 170 new cases were added per month. It is now less than a month until this question closes. For the number to reach the next bracket, 340 new cases would have to be added in the next few weeks. This would be a substantial increase in the rate by which these cases are identified.

Updating: 
4900 limet is passed - so 4300-4900 is no longer possible. 
Seems also less likely that theshold of 5500 will be reached.

Updating my forecast: The number of cases have passed 4900 making that option impossible. The development of cases pretty much followed my initial forecast. With 20 days left the 5500-6300 bucket seems increasingly unlikely, which is why I have decreased its probability to 2 %. The 6300 bucket probability is not 0% but way less that 1% resulting in a round down to 0.

All-time amount of disinformation cases at the time of forecasting (25.03.2019): 5107
Days left: 24  The all-time count exceeded option 1 and 2 already, therefore 0%. In order to estimate the probabilities for the other option, a historic base rate will be identified and its future development will be estimated based on current or upcoming relevant events (such as the EU election in May).  Number of cases in:
February 2019**: 165 
2018: 1215* => monthly average: 101,25
2017: 1321* => monthly average: 110,08
2016: 2023* => monthly average: 168,58  Lower estimated base rate: 105,67 (average of 2017/2018) => estimated 83,15 new cases in next 24 days => 18.04.2019: 5190,15 Middle base rate: 126,64 (average of 2016/2017/2018) => estimated 99,65 new cases in next 24 days => 18.04.2019: 5206,65 Upper estimated base rate: 168,58 (=2016) => estimated 132,65 new cases in next 24 days => 18.04.2019: 5239,65 Unfortunately, there is no additional statistical information available in order to assess the data at hand more detailed. The monthly average of 2017 and 2018 are very similar. In contrast, the average and the final total amount of cases for 2016 are (roughly) 1,6 times higher. This spike could be caused by the US presidential elections and the increased media attention for possible Russian attempts to influence the election. As mentioed before the EU election will take place in May, hence, the election campaigns will start in late March to early April. The EU election represent a similar opportunity to influence the European political landscape as the US election. As a result, it is very likely that the rate for the remaining months will converge with the rate for 2016. An average of 165 cases in February 2019 support this assumption.  As a result: 
For the last two options the  future base rate has to be higher than the 2016 base rate. For 'more than 6300' the rate has to rise by the factor 7. For 'between 5500 and 6300' the rate has to raise by the factor (approx.) 2,5. None are very likely as this means that the Russian Federation would assess the EU elections by far more important the the US election (in the case of a deliberate attempt to influence these elections). However, there is still a realistic chance for an increase by the factor 2,5. The 1% probability is based on the uncertainty involved in such intelligence agency actions and the technological capability of the Russian services. Finally, the probability for more than 4900 and less than 5500 seems to be the most likely outcome.  *(Disclaimer: The used categories of the website aren't distinctive. "For the past year" or "for the past 2 years" could mean '2018/2017' or 'the last 12/24 months from now on'. As a result, there are ambigious results for 2017: GJO states 1215 while there could be only 1110 (total number 'for the past 2 years' substracted by the number of cases 'for the past year'). This forecast will assume that the 'key statistics' are updated daily as there is no date for the last data entry mentioned on the site itself. **(Disclaimer: assuming 'for the last month' = February 2019) Sources: 
EU vs Disinfo (2019): Key statistics of disinformation: https://euvsdisinfo.eu/

Update: 
I confirm this forecast. Today, the all-time count is of 5107 cases. If the count has increased (191 additional cases since late February), I expect the next number of cases not to triple in the upcoming weeks.

The number of all time disinformation reports at the moment is 5107 - and only for the last week the count according to EU EASE StratCom accounts for 32 reports. Having in mind that after a new regulatory body/process is established the reporting procedures of something now abnormal, previously understood as normal becomes more natural, therefore it is expected for more reports to done by the end of the forecasting period, the question is how much more exactly. Last month (February) with 2 days less than a standard month there were 178 disinformation cases. This makes about 6 cases per day. Should the rate of reporting stays stable this will account to a steady reporting of  around 180 for March and around 114 more until 19th April 2018. Of course, the numbers are unstable, but this rough calculation is giving a good reason to think of 200-300 more cases to be reported until 19th April 2019. Adding these to the 5107 will account to slightly less than 5500. However, investigative process is still on, therefore while new disinformation reports are shelved, there are past cases that are being investigated too. Another question of instability currently in my prediction is posed by the question how much of those cases are pro-Kremlin and how much are genuinely no-pro but against a national government view, merely a disinformation active measures. Even taken the last point into consideration, the count that EU EASE Stratcom does seem to include on their website is enforced to be specifically pro-Kremlin disinformation reports, therefore my prediction forecast is that until 19th April 2019 it is highly likely to be below 5500, however, there is a good possibility the reports to rise beyond the calculations and account in the threshold of 5500-6300.
5060 identified to date (20 May 2019), forecast remains the same.

Af of today, we are at 5,014 disinformation cases; thus we can already exclude the first two options. In general, there has been an average of around 100 cases per month so far, which would set the final figure somewhere between 5,100 and 5,200 cases. The third option is thus, by far, the most likely. However, with the upcoming European and Ukranian elections, a sharp and even extreme increase in disinformation cases (capable of reaching up to more than 5,500 total cases) cannot be ruled out. It is however highly unlikey that they will amount to more than 6,300 in just more than a month from now.

0% Less than 4300 and between 4300 and 4900, inclusive
These two possibilities are already impossible to happen because according to https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ the number of episodes of disinformation caused by Russia are already 4973. 80% More than 4900 but less than 5500
On the 18 of April 2018, starting on November 2015, 3946 episodes has been registered, while in the past year starting from 6/3/2019, 4973 have been registered. So, 4973-3946 = 1027 episodes in 10 months and two weeks. This means an average of 97,80 per month. Before the 18th of April it’s around one month and a half, so I expect that 5119 will be the all-time count of pro-Kremlin disinformation cases identified by the European Union External Action Service's East StratCom Task Force.  4973+97,80+(97,8:2) = 5070,8 + 48,9 = 5119,7. Therefore, according to statistics, the outcomes should be in the boundary of 4900 and 5500. 20% Between 5500 and 6300, inclusive
However, I think that the number of registered episodes od disinformation would increase in critical period, like the weeks before the European elections (taking place in the end of May), the Brexit hypothetical agreement (on 29th of March) and the Ukraine presidential elections (in the end of March). Indeed, in the past there has been a peak of disinformation episodes during events like the referendum for Brexit, when Russian trolls were sending thousands of messages pro Brexit,	 (https://www.globalist.it/world/2017/11/15/lo-zampino-della-russia-sul-referendum-della-brexit-allarme-in-gran-bretagna-2014871.html), or during the USA elections in 2016, where the disinformation had the goal to harm Hillary Clinton campaign (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/17/opinion/russia-2016-election-influence-trump.html). If it was influential or not on the results is not the point, but the existence of such a phenomenon is an alert for the European task force. In fact, I believe that the activity of the task force has increased since it has been created (in 2015), with the support of the EU institutions and even the enlargement of the team itself (Jakob Øhrgaard Political Adviser, European Commission Representation). 

0% More than 6300
In spite of what I wrote about the possibility of a peak during special events, I think that this is out of probability because would be too much beyond the statistics.

Update: the current number of identified cases stands at  5020, meaning 40 have been added in the last 14 days. This reflects a slowing in the rate of accumulation (just 20 per week). The likelihood of the total number of cases exceeding 5500 by April 18 is therefore considered to have lessened further.

Since the question at hand has been on for some time now, the first two options can already be ruled out by this forecast. As of today - 2 March 2018 - there already have been 4973 Russian disinformation campaigns registered by the EEAS; thus, a higher number than given in the first two options. The forecast at hand estimates a likelihood of 65% that there will be in total 4901 till 5499 Russian disinformation campaigns noted on 18 April 2019. Even in 2016, a year to be considered very turbulent for wold politics and Russian interests - Brexit, US elections, refugee crises in Europe and Russian supported military operations in Syria, e.g. in Eastern Aleppo (https://www.cfr.org/blog/ten-most-significant-world-events-2016), there were only 2023 Russian disinformation campaigns detected by the EEAS - an average of 169 cases per month. Even if it is assumed that those numbers vary from month to month and peak during events, considered as strategically important to Russia, an increase about more than one third seems rather unlikely, in particular given the fact that last months there were only 178 counted as well. However, three events in March (and May) could lead to a drastic increase of detected information campaigns: First, presidential elections are to be hold in the Ukraine on 31 March 2019. Due to the on-going conflict between Russia and the Ukraine pro-Russian public support has decreased drastically (https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/ukrainealert/why-pro-russian-candidates-won-t-win-ukraine-s-2019-elections). Thus, Russia could expand its disinformation campaigns in order to make up for these losses and prevent a further approximation of the Ukraine and the EU. The UK’s - yet not so sure - exit from the EU is originally planed to be realized on 29 March 2019. Given to Russians previous pro-Brexit engagement (https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2018/10/17/russian-iranian-twitter-trolls-sent-10-million-tweets-fake-news/), a rise of detected case might be counted. Finally, the elections for the EU parliament will be hold between 23 - 26 May 2019. Not only is an increase in Anti-EU disinformation campaigns of Russia expected to happen before (March/April), e.g. to promote anti-EU parties, but also an increased engagement by the EEAS to detect those attacks in order to safeguard the elections. This could also impact the two former mentioned points (Ukraine/Brexit) and will most likely cause an increase in cases detected. Thus the forecast at hand estimates an 35% chance that 5500 - 6300 cases of Russian disinformation campaigns will be detected by the EEAS. Finally, the forecast at hand rules out the fifth option. In 2017, there were a total of 1321 cases detected, when e.g. Germany and France held - for Russia - crucial elections. Thus, it is ruled out that in the next 47 days more cases will be detected (1328) than through all 2017.

The anti-Russia campaign which started in the early 2000s, ever since the Russia govt got mad at america and the west for looting their country in the 90s, is not going to stop anytime soon. The west hates countries that don't accept western criminality, so this will continue until the west dominates Russia, which will probably be never. The westerners are going to keep portraying Russia as evil regardless of elections and good behaviors. There was about:
150 in February 2019
130 in January 2019
100 in December 2018
90 in November 2018 So it looks like the number is increasing over time. 
Though the monthly average for 2016 was 166 and for 2017 was 100 and for 2018 was 95. So it fluctuates randomly.
It is 5000 for all time. There will be 1.7 more months. So the total will be less than 5500 but more than 5000. The total will be about 5150 on april 18.
Currently 4916 cases which means the lower two buckets are eliminated. There are less than 100 cases a month, so the last one is improbable.

Relying on the webpage linked in the question, this forecast looks easily predictable just by a comparison of the data provided:  LESS THAN 4300: According to the database, identified disinformation cases have already reached 4916, as a consequence and unless the system can reconsider cases already assessed, there is a 0% chance that disinformation cases will be less than 4300.  BETWEEN 4300 and 4090: Again, since today the counter has reached 4916, the same considerations given above can be applied also here. Therefore there is a 0% chance.  MORE THAN 5500 BUT LESS THAN  5500: Let's look at the trends. Looking at the database, we can estimate an average of more or less 100 cases reported per month. Therefore, considering that now we are at 4916 cases reported, the likelihood that the number of cases on April 18 will be more than 5500 but less than 5500 is by far the most probable outcome.  BETWEEN 5500 and 6300: This scenario is much less likely than the one above. However, considering that the European Elections will take place in May of the current year, an unprecedented disinformation campaign led by Russia cannot be completely discarded.  MORE THAN 6300: As said, since the upcoming European elections,  a massive campaign led by Russia cannot be completely discarded. However, in this case, the likelihood is even dimmer.

Basing the analysis on the link provided, and with some basic math, we can assume the total number won't exceed the overall number of cases already spotted (4916 at the moment) plus more or less a month and a half worth of cases (between 180 and 250), for a total of 5100-5200 cases. While the first two options are simply impossible (the overall number has already exceeded), the last two projections are still slightly possible, but not probable in the event of a massive fake news campaign.

Since the current number of disinformation cases reached 4916 today, the first propositions — Less than 4300 and Between 4300 and 4900 inclusive — fall with a probability of 0% in this forecast.  90% More than 4900 but less than 5500: Between 18 April 2018 and 24 February 2019, 970 additional disinformation cases have been identified, the all-time count reaching 4916 cases today. This providing an average of 97 cases to be identified per month. However, considering the current context in international affairs e.g Venezuela and the upcoming European elections, the figure of 163 cases identified last month is expected to remain approximatively or increase slightly in the following months. For instance, if multiplied by x1.5 (rather reasonable max. expectation) the all-time count of disinformation cases would be reaching approx. the figure of 5 406 by 18 April 2019.  10% Between 5500 and 6300, inclusive: Rather less likely, the stalemate of international issues and the approaching European elections could lead the count of pro-Kremlin disinformation cases to severely increase the monthly average between February 24 and 18 April 2019.  0% More than 6300 : It is very unlikely that from today to 18 April 2019, the monthly average of identified cases reaches a historical figure, dramatically exceeding the monthly average of 2016 e.g U.S elections.

2016 = 2023 disinformation cases for the year 
2017 = 1321 Disinformation cases for the year  1 January 2018 = 3344 total disinformation cases
18 April 2018 = 3946 total disinformation cases
From 1 January to 18 April = +602 disinformation cases 
2018 = 1115 Disinformation cases for the year 1 January 2019 = 4459 total Disinformation cases 
22 February 2019 = 4916 total disinformation cases 
Between 1 January and 22 February 2019 = +457 disinformation cases Between 18 April 2018 and 22 February 2019 = Increase of 970 disinformation cases Website was started in November 2015
Total of months since today (including February) = 40
Total of days since November 2015 = 1 180 days
The average of disinformation cases per month = 122,9 
The average of disinformation cases per day = 4,17 Deadline : 18 April 2019 (approximately two months, 55 days )
122,9 x 2 (months left) = 245,8
4,17 x 55 (days left) = 229,35
Total disinformation cases on 22 February 2019 (4916) + estimate average per day (4,17 x 55 days left = 229,35) = 5145,35 However, the number disinformation cases from 1 January 2018 to 18 April 2018 (108 days) was 602 and from 1 January 2018 to 22 February 2019 (53 days) was 457.
Average per day for 1 January 2019 to 18 April 2018 = 5,58
Average per day for 1 January 2019 to 22 February 2019 = 8,6
The average of disinformation cases per day is higher in 2019 than in 2018.  Thus, the overall average per day for the 18 April 2019 since November 2015 is 4,17.
But for the beginning of 2019, the average per day is 8,17. 
8,17 x 55 days left = 449,35
Total disinformation cases on 22 February 2019 (4916) + estimate average per day on 2019 (8,17 x 55 days left= 449,35) = 5 365,35 So the estimate total of number disinformation cases differs from 5 145,35 (overall possible total of disinformation cases since November 2015) to 5 365,35 (possible total of disinformation cases according to the numbers of 2019). If we take to account the situation in Venezuela (opposition between EU and USA vs Russia etc..) and the arrival of European election campaigns in the near future, it is not impossible to have an higher average of disinformation cases per day, thus exceeding 5 500 disinformation cases in total.
For example, 2016 was a good example of increasing disinformation cases in regards to the US presidential election.

Less than 4300 and 4300 – 4900, incl: As the current number of pro-Kremlin cases it at 4916, the first two options are automatically ruled out and will be assigned a 0% probability. (Though, the East StratCom Task Force do highlight that in instances where the misinformation cases are proved to in fact be true, they can be taken off the list. Hence, the total case count could decrease should some cases be found invalid.  However, I find that to be very unlikely).   4900- <5500: This is the interval wherein the current case count is found. The past month has seen an addition of 187 new cases. Presuming that this rate will continue, the total number of cases will be app. 5290 by April 18th. Looking at the average number of monthly cases in the past year, the number is only 92. Hence, there has been a significant rise activity in the past month. While this activity could continue to increase e.g. in relation to the nearing EU elections, I do not see a reason to believe that the amount of new cases will exceed 585 by April 18th. I find it very likely that the total number of cases will be found in this interval, hence the 97% probability.  Between 5500 – 6300, incl. and More than 6300: I find it unlikely that the total number of cases will fall in the interval of 5500-6300 and very unlikely that it will exceed 6300. Hence, a probability of 3% and 0% respectively.

As of February 20, 2019, the East StratCom Task force has recorded 4916 Pro-Kremlin Disinformation Cases, which exceeds the lowest two forecasted options.  Therefore, with 57 days remaining in the test period, we are still 584 cases away from reaching the next highest range's minimum value of 5500. East StratCom would need to register an average of 10.2 cases a day for the next two months to reach that benchmark, which greatly exceeds this past week's, month's, and year's averages of 7.3, 6.4, and 3.1 respectively. There has certainly been an acceleration in Pro-Kremlin propaganda over time, but an acceleration extreme enough to reach the next range is very unlikely to occur in the near term.

Based on the number of disinformation cases published on EUvsDisinfo to date (20th February) -- run by the EU External Action Service's East StratCom Task Force -- the possibility of option 1 and (almost) 2 are ruled out by default. Identified cases stand at 4860. For the two months remaining, an approximation of how many cases will be identified can be made. This is done by simply averaging identified cases per month in 2016 and 2017. For 2016, the mean average was 168; for 2017, 110. If these averages are taken for granted, the total number of identified cases by April 18th would range between 5080 (4860+220) and 5196 (4860+336) based on 2016 and 2017 calculations. This range falls within the 4900-5500 category, with a margin on either side that would allows for a diversion from previous years' averages -- making this option highly likely.  2% chance has been allocated to the 5500-6300 to account for the chance of an anomaly. This would require that the number of identified cases between now and April 18 is 320/per month or more -- almost double the monthly averages of 2016 (considerably higher than the preceding year).  This is considered highly unlikely. More unlikely still is the chance of the number of cases exceeding 6300 -- thus it has been given 0%.

Stats as of 20th of February: total number 4860. Past month 135 cases. Past year 1071 cases. 1071/12 = 89,25 cases pr. month in 2018. 
There are two month remaining. 
Less than 4300: Impossible 
4300-4900: With two month remaining we will easely get 40 more cases even if the disinformation activity slows down. 
4900-5500: By far the safest bet. If we get 135 cases pr. month as in the first month of 2019 we will be up on. 5130 cases in total. 
5500-6300: very unlikely. The activity must go significantly up. 5500 - 4860 = 640. 640/2 = 320 cases pr. month to reach 5500. This requires more than 3,5 times increase in activity each month compared to 2018 average. 
over 6300: almost impossible. We need something extraordinary for that to happen.  Perhaps direct and clear orders from Kremlin to level up. Or East Stratcoms way to classify disinformation changes drastically.

On the 18th of February 2019 the total count has reached 4860 ruling out option 1 and making option 2 very unlikely.  The information on this page suggest an average of around 120-140 a month in 2016 and 2017. With exactly two months left, a conservative estimate would be 5060 (4860+200) and a bold estimate 5180 (4860+320) making option 3 a choice with a safe margin on either side.  Option 4 would require very high disinformation activity with more than double the average monthly amount, and option 5 can be ruled out since we would need to see the same amount of cases in the next two months as what have normally been found in a year.

18 of april 2018= 3946
18 of february = 4860 4860-3946 = 914 in 10 months. 91 per month.
2 months left 182 plus 4860 = 5042 firmly within the 4900-5500 boundary

Improved log-LR (non-autoregressive): de-seasonalizing with semi-annual split plus winter break (weeks 50 and 1), dropping weekly dummies;
resampling residuals yielded median counts 5082 with narrow confidence interval (IQR=34).

Prediction from refined model with 2 stages: 
1) project the count at the end of winter break (2019.01.17), using a seasonally adjusted temporal regression (annual and weekly dummies)
2) from that point onward, run an AR(2) simulation with resampled residuals
 This yielded a median forecast of 5049 cases (IQR=140), where out of 2500 bootstrapped fits 99 ones had their endpoint falling below 4900.
Zero-order model: taking the current production (3.58 case/day), added to the base number at 2018.12.17.

Okay, from GJOpen we now the following:
- 2016: 2023 cases, on average 169 cases per month
- 2017: 1321 cases, on average 110 cases per month According to https://euvsdisinfo.eu/, the last year had 960 cases and the last month (August, I suppose, maybe also July) had 0 cases. I assume the number hasn't been updated yet. So, the last year goes from roughly September 2017 to September 2018. For a rough approximation, I assume that every month had the same amount of cases and conclude, that 2018 so far saw 7/11 * 960 = 636 cases, with an average monthly rate of 87 cases.  Now, the rate of new cases has decreased significantly over the last 2 years, so it seems sensible to include this, too. I'll just guess that it will fall to an average of 70 cases per month in the months till April.  In total, as of today, we have 4214 cases. If I expect 70 cases per month until April, and that August hasn't been updated yet, my point estimate would be about 4214 + 665 = 4879. Reasons for doubt and uncertainty:
- can I expect future decrease in numbers from the past? This might have been caused by developments that change (elections in the EU as targets, arms race between disinformers and task force)
- assumptions might be false (have there been 0 cases in the last month?)
- I don't know how cases are classified (it is rated for being a false information that is "in line with usual pro-Kremlin disinformation messaging". Also, the exact details might change in the future and more or less instances will be classified as misinformation.
- this ignores the seemingly ever decreasing rate of new cases Based on that, I will intuitively distribute the probability clay.  	1) 2% - Less than 4300
	2) 48% - Between 4300 and 4900, inclusive
	3) 40% - More than 4900 but less than 5500
	4) 10% - Between 5500 and 6300, inclusive
	5) 0% - More than 6300 What do the top comments and consensus votes say? 	- JMR2017 has way higher extrapolations compared to mine, it seems because the number of cases this year has not been rising much since his prediction in April. He expects a rise due the midterm elections in the US, which leds me to update a little towards higher numbers.

	2) 45% - Between 4300 and 4900, inclusive

"new study has identified 6,500 Russian Twitter accounts that actively promoted U.K. Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn in the weeks before Britain’s June 2017 general election. The joint investigation by The Sunday Times and Swansea University revealed that many of the Russian accounts were in fact bots using 15-character alphanumeric usernames accompanied by a false English-sounding woman’s name. 
For example, the Twitter user @NR2AtERXvfDy0N was named Gabrielle Wilson and @3udLH4vNxhmDksX appeared as Jessica Ferguson.
The accounts listed their language or location as Russian.
The majority of them, 80 percent, were created in the weeks preceding the vote and most of them were later suspended by Twitter or disappeared.
Academics from Swansea say the 6,500 accounts are just “the tip of the iceberg” in a large-scale Russian campaign to influence British voters"
The study found that nine out of 10 messages posted by the Russian accounts about the Labour Party promoted its election campaign. On the other hand, nine out of 10 tweets about the Conservative Party were hostile. 
Matt Hancock, Britain’s digital and culture secretary, described the revelations as “extremely concerning” and said it was “absolutely unacceptable for any nation to attempt to interfere in the democratic elections of another country.” Further reading: Timeline: How Russia Built Two Major Disinformation Campaigns Figure of the Week: 18 Figure of the Week: 45,000 share with

" President Donald Trump has barely acknowledged that Russians meddled in the 2016 presidential election, and now it looks like he’s doing nothing to prevent Moscow from interfering again. Adm. Michael Rogers, who leads US Cyber Command, told lawmakers on Tuesday that Trump has yet to direct him to strike Russia’s cyber operations where they start. That means Russian President Vladimir Putin — who directed the campaign to disrupt the last US presidential election — has yet to see any serious repercussions for his country’s actions. Worse, there are almost no substantive measures in place to prevent Russia from meddling in the upcoming 2018 midterm elections. The problem, according to Rogers, is he needs specific authorization from the president to go on offense and directly disrupt the hackers’ operations. Without that, he sees no reason why Russia would stop trying to tamper with US elections anytime soon. Rogers did mention, however, that he already ordered some secret measures to defend against Russia’s interference before the next ballots are cast in a few months. “If we don’t change the dynamic here, this is going to continue, and 2016 won’t be viewed as something isolated,” Rogers told the Senate Armed Services Committee. “This is something that will be sustained over time.” Michael Sulmeyer, a former top cyber official at the Pentagon, also feels the US should target Russia’s election hackers. “You don’t just wait here and play defense, you also go out and stop this from happening again,” he told me."

Vox:
"President Donald Trump has barely acknowledged that Russians meddled in the 2016 presidential election, and now it looks like he’s doing nothing to prevent Moscow from interfering again.
 Adm. Michael Rogers, who leads US Cyber Command, told lawmakers on Tuesday that Trump has yet to direct him to strike Russia’s cyber operations where they start. That means Russian President Vladimir Putin — who directed the campaign to disrupt the last US presidential election — has yet to see any serious repercussions for his country’s actions.
Worse, there are almost no substantive measures in place to prevent Russia from meddling in the upcoming 2018 midterm elections. The problem, according to Rogers, is he needs specific authorization from the president to go on offense and directly disrupt the hackers’ operations. Without that, he sees no reason why Russia would stop trying to tamper with US elections anytime soon. Rogers did mention, however, that he already ordered some secret measures to defend against Russia’s interference before the next ballots are cast in a few months.
“If we don’t change the dynamic here, this is going to continue, and 2016 won’t be viewed as something isolated,” Rogers told the Senate Armed Services Committee. “This is something that will be sustained over time.”
Michael Sulmeyer, a former top cyber official at the Pentagon, also feels the US should target Russia’s election hackers. “You don’t just wait here and play defense, you also go out and stop this from happening again,” he told me.

" As tempting as it may be to write these people off, the numbers are a little staggering: 126 million people saw Russian disinformation, per Mark Zuckerberg, the ads just released were seen by 33 million, and 3.7 million people clicked them. And the idea was always to push division, as seen by tactics like flooding Facebook with ads from groups like “Black Matters” after Dylann Roof murdered nine black people at a church in Charleston, SC." 5-12-2018 update
1) Protect election infrastructure. Trump should direct states to upgrade voter registration systems, voting machines, tally servers, and any other machinery that helps collect and verify votes. While federal officials have done a lot to improve the equipment since the 2016 election, the government could do a lot more.
“We need to replace outdated systems,” said Lawrence Norden, an elections expert at the Brennan Center for Justice at the New York University School of Law, including “replacing paperless electronic voting machines” and “conducting post-election audits to compare the paper records to software generated results.” 2) Improve transparency in social media. The Russians used fake social media accounts to sow divisions in the United States among racial, ethnic, gender, and partisan lines — in part by paying for bogus advertisements. The government could put more pressure on Twitter and Facebook to better identify where the money for ad buys come from, according to Claire Finkelstein, an elections expert at the University of Pennsylvania. Similarly, these companies could also help users better identify what is — and is not — “fake news.” 3) Deter Russia from interfering again. One way the US could do this is use covert action and information operations to make it harder for Russian hackers to do their job, Glenn Carle, a former CIA officer, told Stewart. If the hackers have to spend more time fighting off American attacks, they have less time to meddle in the election. Further, Sulmeyer told me that the US could empower members of its military cyber forces to attack Russian hackers. That would directly punish the people who most prominently tampered with the US election process.
 The problem is the Trump administration has done little in each of these areas — and other leaders have started to take matters into their own hands.
Here are just a few examples: The Boston Globe reports Virginia election officials have returned to using paper ballots; Pennsylvania’s government wants election equipment to produce paper records of votes; and Georgia may also use paper instead of using touch screens.
There are good reasons for states to worry. Department of Homeland Security officials confirmed in a June 2017 Senate intelligence hearing that Russia targeted at least 21 states, and hackers probed their registration systems. However, only Illinois election officials testified to a breach — “a malicious cyber-attack of unknown origin” that hit the Illinois voter registration system and allowed hackers to access 90,000 voter registration record. If the US is going to disrupt these attacks, the only sure protection for election infrastructure
is paper ballots. The only deterrence comes from unleashing the unique advantages of NSA/CIA in any realm of cyber-warfare US has superiority See Stuxnet, DPRK missile failures... might be time to take some serious and sustained attacks at the most vital part of Russian cash-crash Gazprom's and Rosneft pipelines for a few days is certain to get attention. Collapsing Russian oil and gas production  for a time period would deter.   Datasets like this seem useless, but any data set is useless if US will not punch back
Transparency in social media? Zuckerberg is keen to advertise the new friendlier FACEBOOK
twice the monitors....
